marketNews.title: Government Plans to Extend Credit Restructuring Relaxation
marketNews.content:
Minister of Economic Affairs Airlangga Hartarto said that President Joko Widodo requested the relaxation of credit restructuring for Covid-19‑affected loans be extended until 2025. The proposal aims to reduce the burden on the banking industry in provisioning for losses from non‑performing People's Business Credit (KUR).

Airlangga said the proposal will be followed up through the Financial System Stability Committee (KSSK) and the Governor of Bank Indonesia. In response, the Chairman of the OJK Board of Commissioners Mahendra Siregar said that the regulator will take deeper steps and evaluate the credit restructuring program that has been running.

The Covid‑19‑affected credit restructuring relaxation originally started in March 2020 and was supposed to end in March 2024. Although its term has ended, OJK still gives banks time to continue the restructuring that is already underway.

With the end of the relaxation, loans that have been restructured but remain problematic will no longer be classified as performing, but will move to the problematic category. As a result, banks must charge a provisioning cost to create reserves for those problematic loans.

Below is a summary of the development of Covid‑19‑affected credit restructuring:

Key Takeaway

We assess that if the proposal is implemented, it could have a positive impact on banks' net profit in the short term due to reduced provisioning burden from the re‑classification of problematic loans. On the other hand, if the restructured loans do not improve, the policy in the long term will only postpone the classification of bad loans.

marketNews.title: Various Economic and Policy Updates
marketNews.content:
Deputy III of the Presidential Staff Edy Priyono said the government predicts Indonesia will face a rice deficit in July 2024 as national rice production fell 20.9% year‑on‑year to 10.27 million tons in the first four months of 2024.

Trade Minister Zulkifli Hasan said the retail price ceiling (HET) for cooking oil will rise next week from 14,000 rupiah per liter to 15,700 rupiah per liter, higher than the initially planned increase to 15,500 rupiah per liter.

Bank Indonesia Governor Perry Warjiyo said in a meeting with the DPR on Monday (24/6) that the central bank does not see an urgent need to raise the policy interest rate to stabilize the rupiah. This assessment is based on relatively low inflation, and further rate hikes would negatively affect economic growth. Perry also expressed optimism that the rupiah will strengthen to a fundamental level below 16,000 per US dollar.

Finance Minister Sri Mulyani said the 2024 state budget recorded a deficit of 21.8 trillion rupiah or 0.1% of GDP as of May 2024. The deficit was driven by state revenue which fell 7.1% year‑on‑year to 1,123.5 trillion rupiah, equal to 40.1% of the 2024 budget target, due to declines across all revenue items. Meanwhile, actual government spending rose 14% year‑on‑year to 1,145.3 trillion rupiah, equal to 34.4% of the 2024 budget target.

The World Bank suggested the Indonesian government lower the taxable income threshold for companies to boost state revenue. World Bank Chief Economist Habib Rab said the current corporate tax threshold in Indonesia is six times higher than in OECD countries. Director at the Directorate General of Taxes Dwi Astuti said the agency is discussing the proposal internally.

Eramet and BASF SE announced they will cancel a joint‑venture nickel smelter investment worth 2.6 billion US dollars in Weda Bay. BASF told Bloomberg that they no longer see a need for the investment as global electric‑battery supply increases.

NFC Indonesia, through its subsidiary PT Energi Selalu Baru (ESB), announced it has acquired 50% of the shares in Infi Asia E‑Mobility Pte. Ltd. with an undisclosed transaction value. The move aims to accelerate ESB’s expansion into the main Southeast Asian markets, including Thailand, Malaysia and Vietnam. ESB is a producer of Volta electric scooters. As of 1Q24, ESB has facilitated more than 665,000 battery‑swap transactions through 299 swap stations.

tickerNews.title: JSMR to Divest 35% Stake in Transjawa Toll Road Next Week
tickerNews.content: JSMR: Chairman of Metro Pacific Tollways Corp. (MPTC), Manuel V. Pangilinan, said that the company will sign a transaction to acquire 35% of the shares of PT Jasamarga Transjawa Toll (JTT) next week. Manuel did not specify the total value of the transaction. However, MPTC – the parent of Nusantara Infrastructure (META) – last year estimated that its joint venture with GIC Pte. Ltd. would invest 600 million USD (approximately 9.78 trillion rupiah) to acquire a 35% stake in JTT.

tickerNews.title: AMMN Share Transfer and Estate Planning Transaction
tickerNews.content: AMMN: Holder of 5.16 billion (7.11%) shares of Amman Mineral Internasional, PT Alpha Investasi Mandiri, is transferring its entire ownership in AMMN proportionally to its shareholders, who are Alexander Ramlie, Thomas Ramlie, and Charles Daniel Gobel, on 25 July 2024. Alexander Ramlie – the President Director of AMMN – then transferred his entire holding of 5.13 billion (7.08%) AMMN shares to foreign companies he controls, including Sajir 9 LLC, Miracle Milestone Ltd., and Fennel Field LLC. The entire transaction was executed at a price of 1,695 rupiah per share. The transaction is intended for estate planning and is not a sale to third parties.

tickerNews.title: TOTL Reports New Contract Value Reaching 94.2% of 2024 Target
tickerNews.content: TOTL: Investor Relations of Total Bangun Persada, Kevin Alexander, stated that the company has recorded new contract values amounting to 3.3 trillion rupiah up to mid‑June 2024, equivalent to 94.2% of the 2024 target of 3.5 trillion rupiah. TOTL does not plan to raise the 2024 new contract target.

tickerNews.title: CLPI Announces 2023 Dividend with 75% Payout Ratio
tickerNews.content: CLPI: Colorpak Indonesia will distribute a dividend for the 2023 fiscal year amounting to 39.3 billion rupiah, or 128.25 rupiah per share, representing a 75% dividend payout ratio. The dividend is cum‑dividend in the regular and negotiated markets on 3 July 2024, with payment on 26 July 2024. Based on the CLPI share price on Tuesday (25/6) at 1,180 rupiah per share, the implied dividend yield is 10.9%.

tickerNews.title: CAMP Declares 2023 Dividend with 92.36% Payout Ratio
tickerNews.content: CAMP: Campina Ice Cream Industry will distribute a dividend for the 2023 fiscal year amounting to 117.7 billion rupiah, or 20 rupiah per share, representing a 92.36% dividend payout ratio. The dividend is cum‑dividend in the regular and negotiated markets on 1 July 2024, with payment on 25 July 2024. Based on the CAMP share price on Tuesday (25/6) at 414 rupiah per share, the implied dividend yield is 4.8%.

tickerNews.title: TPMA Announces Arrival of 12 New Vessel Sets Worth $50 Million
tickerNews.content: TPMA: Director of Trans Power Marine, Rudy Sutiono, said that the subsidiary PT Trans Logistik Perkasa will receive 12 new vessel sets out of the 15 sets already ordered. The total cost of the 12 vessel sets amounts to 50 million US dollars. Rudy did not specify when the vessels will arrive or become operational.

tickerNews.title: GOTO Founder Purchases 98.5 Million Shares at 51 IDR Each
tickerNews.content: GOTO: President Director of GoTo Gojek Tokopedia, Sugito Walujo, purchased 98.5 million GOTO shares at a price of 51 rupiah per share on 20 June 2024. The total transaction value is approximately 5 billion rupiah. After this transaction, Sugito Walujo’s ownership in GOTO increased from 0.02% to 0.03%.

tickerNews.title: TAPG Forms Joint Venture to Produce Bio‑Coke from Palm Oil Shells
tickerNews.content: TAPG: Triputra Agro Persada announced the establishment of a joint venture with Aisin Takaoka Co. Ltd. to produce bio‑coke based on palm oil shells. The joint venture is targeted to start production in the second half of 2025.

tickerNews.title: AGII Announces New Air‑Separation Plant and 2023 Dividend
tickerNews.content: AGII: President Director of Samator Indo Gas, Rachmat Harsono, said that a new plant in the Batang Integrated Industrial Estate will officially operate in August or September 2024. The plant will be the 56th air‑separation plant of AGII and will also be the company’s largest production facility. In a separate announcement, AGII will distribute a dividend for the 2023 fiscal year amounting to 10.8 rupiah per share, representing a 20% dividend payout ratio and indicating a dividend yield of 0.6% based on the Tuesday (25/6) share price.
